awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Stochastic Approximations for the Solution and Uncertainty Analysis of Data-Intensive Inverse Problems
awd_abstract_narration:
In scientific fields ranging from geophysics and atmospheric science to medical imaging and network communication, data are being generated at remarkable rates. Such data are typically indirectly related to quantities of interest and the data sets are in many cases dynamically growing. Extracting desired information from these data then requires the solution of very large data-intensive inverse problems, perhaps repeatedly and in real time. The computational challenges of obtaining such a solution are compounded by the demands of validation and uncertainty analysis, which can easily become computationally prohibitive. This project will develop mathematical/statistical methods and computational tools for the solution of data-intensive inverse problems. The core of this approach is a stochastic reformulation of such problems that aims to significantly reduce the computational costs while adapting to modern hardware architectures.

A framework will be developed to address the challenges arising at the interface between big data, inverse problems, data analysis, and uncertainty quantification.  First, randomized methods for the solution of linear and nonlinear inverse problems will be introduced, so that efficient stochastic optimization methods can be used to overcome the hardware limitations of current algorithms and to generate solutions and uncertainty assessments in near-real time. New theory and scalable methods will be developed within the stochastic framework, thereby ensuring solution accuracy, reliability, and robustness. Second, advanced tools will be developed for model validation, error analysis, and uncertainty quantification. By partnering with application scientists (e.g., in atmospheric remote sensing), methods developed in this project will be of immediate practical utility for scientists and engineers.

por.por_cntn:
For many data-intensive applications, the massive size of data sets presents fundamental computational challenges to data analysis. This project has addressed these challenges by supporting the development of sophisticated mathematical and statistical tools for computing solutions of large-scale ill-posed inverse problems and for subsequent uncertainty quantification. 

We developed new stochastic approximation methods for the efficient solution of large inverse problems, which have significantly reduced data requirements and overcome hardware limitations. We integrated stochastic approximation methods for (1) linear problems, where rigorous theory and analysis provide justification and insight, (2) linear ill-posed problems, where regularization and parameter selection in the context of stochastic approximation are relatively under-explored, and (3) nonlinear problems, where proper integration of stochasticity is critical for efficiency. 

The award has resulted in 13 peer-reviewed publications, including publications in esteemed journals such as the SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, IOP Inverse Problems, and the Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics. The research developments have been broadly disseminated in the scientific community, including reviewed publications in Scale Space and Variational Methods in Computer Vision and Numerical Algebra, Control and Optimization.  In addition to over 60 invited talks and colloquia given by the PIs, students and postdocs gave numerous contributed talks and posters at national and international conferences during this CDS&E award. The developed methods are being used by research groups worldwide and with new-found connections to training machine learning algorithms, the stochastic approaches developed in this project are growing steadily in popularity and broad utility.

In addition to mathematical contributions to the field of computational and data-intensive inverse problems, the broader impacts of this project include various educational efforts and the development and dissemination of open-source code.  The project supported many undergraduate and graduate students on research projects.  The project also supported the development of new courses in computational modeling and data analytics, as well as K-12 outreach.
